comments.commentBody: It's long past time that customers tell people who are robbing us left and right that we're not going to put up with it anymore. Our family is multiracial, and both of my children are under six. Since they began nursery school, they've been surrounded by many races and many children of mixed ethnicities. They've also been surrounded by many gay men and women in our personal life, and my son had three lesbian families in his first year of preschool that carried into his pre-K class. Diversity is such a mundane part of our daily life that my kids don't recognize it as such.

We don't really talk much about skin color or why someone has two mommies. We haven't avoided questions or made any effort not to address the topics--they simply haven't come up. Our kids have, thus far, blindly accepted that there are families with more than one mommy or daddy, and that their own mom is paler than they. In fact, the things that fascinate them are not the things most people would expect--they are riveted by the fact that I am left-handed and blue-eyed, and they are very impressed by one of their friends' moms who goes fishing regularly. What excites them right now is the unusual things people do and the unique traits they possess. Being different is exciting to them. I'm sure wanting to fit in will become the norm for them at some point, but until then, we'll all faithfully believe in the truths that surround us: Having two mommies or daddies is not only okay, it's normal, and so is having a white mom and a brown dad (or vice versa). Being left-handed...now that's interesting.

It is a poorly kept secret in Greece that Papandreou is a Turkophile -yes, there such sort of Greeks.  He would rather have Greece associated with Ankara than with Brussels. There is, after all, the record of more than four hundred years of Greek submission to the Ottoman yoke. Four hundred years transformed the Greeks. Though Christians, they have greater affinity with their former masters than with the Germans or the French. Greece is too small and poor to stand alone. Their economic future may lie in re-creating, along with Turkey, the Ottoman Empire in everything but name.

Random thoughts:

It would have been niftier if the word "A" had been in the theme answers (e.g. AHAYNEEDLESTACK), both to make the answers more accurate and to reduce the number of cheater squares (the one or two black squares on the lines containing the theme answers which fill up the spaces left over because the them answers are pnly 13 and 14 letters long.)

Yesterday some people were putting GIS (G.I.'s) where INF (infantry) was supposed to go. Today, GIS is in the puzzle. I think there's a word for that. Is it ACME's "malapop"? I don't know if that word covers a two-day span.

The phrase "give A LEG up" is in this puzzle, too. I thought the expression was "have a leg up." Bing results shows my version on top by a healthy margin. But it also proves "give" is not unknown.

I saw the misdirection in "Jobs plan" right away (i.e. Steve rather than occupations) but I still don't see why an IMAC is, or was, a plan. I thought it was a computer. (God are those blue blobs ugly.)

I was concerned where the clue "weenie" was going.

"Chimpersonators" was a great clue. Of course, I knew exactly where it was going right away. Clever, but a giveaway.

"Mardi follower" should have been MERCREDI, non? But of course.

"Having less fat" implies a comparison that wasn't there; for the answer to be LITE, I'd have expected "Low in fat." But LEANER didn't fit.

Re the clue for HOPI: How come the normal spelling NAVAJO appears more in clues than in answers?

I had to think of the IP address answer for a while, too. Thought it was clever when I got it. And HTTP wasn't going to fit.

Most human transactions are built on trust as the ultimate glue. Whether it's the relationship between spouses or the relationships that make a government work.

We have no way of knowing today whether senior ministers of the government of India are telling the truth or not. Can we believe the bureaucrats?

How do we know that whatever documents are being presented have not been wantonly and suitably modified?

Democracy is not about rulers and the ruled. Yet, in India, that seems to be precisely the case. The gap between the two is so wide that they seem to belong to two different planets. This is not the stuff of democracy by any yardstick.

The challenge is tough as the ignorance of the citizenry is vast and the sense of being the ruling class is too deeply ingrained among the accidental occupants of various powerful offices.

Oh! Is India trying to flex its muscles as a regional superpower? India should be careful and not get too over-confident about its capabilities. One can never be sure that the project's end results will be quite what India might have planned or hoped for.

It's unfortunate if decisions are not being made. The reason could be that everyone thinks of themselves as superior to everyone else.

I’m shocked at the number of people on their high horses ready to judge somebody on a matter they have little/no experience of. I wonder how many of them who probably left a small town here in the US to get a higher education and a good job will quit everything,  go back where they came from and start over. It pales in comparison to what the author did, but it will give a little perspective to what he wanted to convey in this article. Extreme poverty, rampant corruption at all levels, deep social differences and so many other problems that are part of daily life in a developing country can be so overwhelming that one feels totally helpless and hopeless. I too came from a developing country to get a higher education and stayed. I completely understand the well-intentioned desire to go back and the agonizing decision to leave again. I wish people were more open minded/understanding and less quick to judge.

This would strike me as a wonderful piece if it were not for my encounter with a would-be groom from the US last year. Director of a major Fortune 500 MNC (still), Ivy League educated, the bride agreed to the marriage imagining such ideals of liberal thought as enunciated here. Two weeks before the wedding, he demanded a dowry, saris for his extended family and more by blackmailing the brides family that he would not come otherwise. He thought the family would give in to his demands. Instead the bride refused to go to the wedding hall and her family stood by her. Mr Groom arrived there blue in the face and embarrassed beyond measure and had to catch his lonely flight back to the USA. NRIs seem to talk the talk, but are not capable of walking the talk. Their liberal thoughts are thoughts only. You may shout at our hawkers and urchins and maids. You do. We don't. We build our relationships with them that we and they know. You don't get to comment on how much of family my maid is to me. You came here treating your help badly and that guilt and the sin sir, is yours alone. Not mine. Truth is, most liberal Indians living here have moved beyond this 1970s concept of India you returned to. You were stuck in a time warp. Like most NRIs. Go back. You can't handle the truth.

People will glibly talk about the demographic dividend.

I'd like to force such bozos to live in the crowded parts of Delhi for a while — say, an year. A few may come out of the searing competition for opportunities as smart — even as a genius. But millions will be inevitably forced to live lives of unimaginable squalor, both physical and moral; and poverty, both physical and mental.

How does one persuade a million — no, nearly a billion — individuals that life is about learning and self-improvement. A journey. Making babies is not the be all and end all of that journey.

Who'll make a beginning? Who'll take the first steps? Are the educated ones any better than the illiterate ones? The strange reality is that in India, it's quite fashionable to have babies — irrespective of one's financial status or standing.

In such a scenario, the future is at best hazily uncertain. Hopefully, science will prevent any kind of extraordinary or unprecedented human calamity.

And humans can merrily carry on till the next billion is reached — and the billion after that.

Sumedh,

I was brought up in a house where we didn't mention the cost of things in front of servants, we didn't leave price tags of clothing lying about, we fed our servants whatever we ate (even Italian, Chinese and Mediterranean), we gave our servants a pay raise every-time we got one, gave them the same chocolates and cookies that we would give our nephews and nieces. All very simple, obvious and human things. Nothing special. And what we get in return was unswerving loyalty, devotion and service in return. Our house was always given top priority by them, come rain, sun or hail. And having them, made life really comfortable for us. Perhaps if you tried some of these things (not just with servants but everybody around who is less lucky than you) instead of subscribing to age old norms, Bangalore would have treated you a bit better.
Ofcourse, India has loads of people who con you for your money. Once in a while everybody gets conned. But isnt that one con worth it for all the times you helped somebody?

-Pranav
